R: @dhalperi
R: @dhalperi
Also, swapping away from TestDataflowRunner will leak (more) jobs since any streaming jobs that throw will never get cancelled.

Rather than lumping it inside ApiSurfaceTest, could we put it a package-private ClassPath.java (e.g.), so that `ApiSurfaceTest` is essentially a no-op both here and once we can delete this code? Seems safer going forward.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/11317026/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/11317026)

Coverage decreased (-0.03%) to 70.115% when pulling **aa7119faf3c2457d5201f6f77b94c60ae71b4c9a on staslev:BEAM-1676-api-surface-tests-fail-with-spaces-in-dir-name** into **535761a7451c3e1dc557a58c35f2190e05c68aac on apache:master**.

In fact, the real problem here is that the tests in question are not black box end-to-end tests, in which case `DataflowRunner` is the only runner that provides true coverage.

But the tests that use these options are just failsafe ITs, which could certainly use `PAssert` and whatnot. I'll switch it back to `TestDataflowRunner` for that reason and tweak the options here or possibly via a temporary hack in `TestPipeline`.

less Proto, as we should not declare a dependency on the proto module in the dataflow module, or vice versa.

This unfortunately means that ProtoCoder must be java-serialized in Dataflow until the runner api serialization is complete, and the dataflow runner is ported to use it.
Looks to me like the loss of buffer size control has broken things. I believe the intent was to be able to use the CreateOptions to pass this type of info in. Take a look?


Yes taking a look.

https://builds.apache.org/view/Beam/job/beam_PostCommit_Java_MavenInstall/3558/
LGTM once green. Thanks for this!!

This is not the right level for retrying. The retry should happen around `submit_job_description`. This function has side effects like creating files in GCS location etc. and does not have a clean way for retrying. On the other `submit_job_description` is the integration point and is limited to http request.
run dataflow validatesrunner

@robertwb your comment sounds like we are removing a capability, but this seems to be implementing the compromise whereby users can still output here - they just need to track the windows, which they needed to do anyhow.
Have you read the spec? It is both nonsensical and not type safe.
The reason it is a stable release blocker is that we want to remove the incorrect behavior and always have the option to add supplementary functionality as we figure out how to do so correctly.

I have read the spec; I helped come up with it. It was a compromise between
many options (including requiring explicit windowing in FinalizeOutputs,
which is actually much less typesafe as explicitly emitting to the
GlobalWindow when the ambient windowing function is something else will not
be caught eagerly and can result in undefined behavior (including possibly
silent data corruption)). The current spec will at least give a clear
error.

On Mon, May 1, 2017 at 11:05 AM, Kenn Knowles <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> The reason it is a stable release blocker is that we want to remove the
> incorrect behavior and always have the option to add supplementary
> functionality as we figure out how to do so correctly.

@kennknowles The issue is that the TestSparkPipelineOptions aren't registered so parsing logic doesn't know how to parse the flag in WordCount.main, I'm unsure as to why WordCountIT was able to parse them in TestPipeline.testingPipelineOptions using PipelineOptionsFactory.fromArgs because WordCountIT doesn't have any references to TestSparkPipelineOptions

Yea, I figured that much out, but I couldn't diagnose further. What is the story around parsing args for runners, since they will generally not be imported? I would expect this to be a totally normal situation - there's a runtime dep activated by `-P spark-runner`.
